Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Low-Energy Architectures for Machine Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Machine learning systems and classifiers will be part of future smart devices. Industrial internet-of-things (IIOT) and cyber-physical systems (CPS) will be equipped with real-time feature extraction and classification to provide feedback and/or warning signals in some cases. Smart medical devices can analyze signals and trigger therapy to improve human health. Security systems can analyze activity data and thwart planned attacks. Reducing energy consumption in these smart devices is critical for increasing battery life in portable applications. This proposal addresses techniques to reduce energy consumption in feature extraction and classification. The broader impacts will be in demonstrating a new approach for feature extraction and classification with significantly less energy consumption without degrading sensitivity and specificity, along with training and educating graduate and undergraduate students in related disciplines through laboratory and computational experiences.

The proposed framework computes features and classifies the test data using a simple level-1 classifier that makes use of low precision. If the classification is successful, then the process terminates. Otherwise the level-2 classifier is invoked. The level-2 classifier makes use of higher precision for the feature extraction and classification; however, it reuses the low-precision results of the level-1 classifier. The process is repeated in an iterative manner until the test sample is classified with a high probability. The proposed approach differs from existing approaches in the sense that the classifier at a certain level is trained using only the training samples that do not contain the samples that were correctly classified in prior levels. The precision at the different levels of feature extraction and classification are the same for both training and test phases. This is expected to lead to higher classification accuracy. The features and classifiers are computed using approximate computing in an incremental manner. Other innovative aspects include: selection of classes of features that require less energy (e.g., time-domain vs. frequency-domain), ranking of these features using techniques such as minimally-redundant maximally-relevant (mRMR) and use of classifiers such as classification and regression tree (CART) or AdaBoost. Approximate computing of features and classifiers in an incremental manner will be investigated to reduce overall energy consumption while maintaining high sensitivity and specificity. Training of the P-Boost classifier and testing the classifier will be based on same precision; thus there is no disconnect between the precision of the classifiers used for training and testing. The proposed "holistic" approach is likely to result in significant savings in energy consumption compared to state-of-the-art machine learning systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Machine learning systems and classifiers will be part of future smart devices. Industrial internet-of-things (IIOT) and cyber-physical systems (CPS) will be equipped with real-time feature extraction and classification to provide feedback and/or warning signals in some cases. Smart medical devices can analyze signals and trigger therapy to improve human health. Security systems can analyze activity data and thwart planned attacks. Reducing energy consumption in these smart devices is critical for increasing battery life in portable applications. This proposal addresses techniques to reduce energy consumption in feature extraction and classification in machine learning systems.

This research has led to a new approach to data-path design, referred to as incremental-precision, where precision can be varied on-demand. In the incremental-precision approach, first the desired feature is computed using lower precision. Then when a higher-precision feature is required, only the feature is computed for the incremental precision and that result is combined with the earlier lower-precision result. Thus, recomputing the lower-precision part is eliminated. This process is repeated as the precision is varied on-demand. Note that the proposed approach leads to an approximate result as some precision is lost in merging the results of two different precisions. This incremental-precision based datapath computation had not been proposed before. Specifically, incremental-precision architectures were demonstrated to compute fast Fourier transforms of "real" signals and linear discriminant classifiers.

This research demonstrated that multi-level classification can be combined with incremental-precision datapath approach to reduce energy consumption of internet-of-things. In particular, 30% energy reduction was demonstrated for a cyber-physical system that detects seizures in subjects with epilepsy from electroencephalograms. A logistic-regression classifier was used in this application. In the proposed approach, training of the multi-level classifier and testing the classifier are based on same precision; thus there is no disconnect between the precision of the classifiers used for training and testing

Future work needs to be directed towards applications of the proposed approach to compute other classes of features and other classifiers. Future work needs to be directed towards demonstration of the proposed approach in other applications.

[2] Koteshwara, Sandhya and Parhi, Keshab K.. "Low-Energy Architectures of Linear Classifiers for IoT Applications using Incremental Precision and Multi-Level Classification," Proc. 2018 ACM Great Lakes Symposium on VLSI (GLSVLSI), 2018. doi:10.1145/3194554.3194603
